definitions.definition: to close an envelope, etc. by sticking the edges of the opening together

examples.text: Make sure you've signed the document before sealing the envelope.
a **sealed bid** *(= one that is kept in a sealed  and therefore remains secret until all other bids have been received)

definitions.definition: to close a container tightly or fill a small opening, etc., especially so that air, liquid, etc. cannot get in or out

examples.text: He sealed the bag tightly with sticky tape.
The windows and doors had been sealed up with bricks.
The evidence is kept in sealed plastic bags.
The containers must be carefully sealed so that no air can get in.
The whole unit is sealed to prevent dust getting in.

definitions.definition: to make something definite, so that it cannot be changed or argued about

examples.text: They shook hands to seal the deal.
The discovery of new evidence **sealed his fate** *(= nothing could prevent what was going to happen to him)*.
She sealed victory with a birdie at the final hole.

definitions.definition: to cover the surface of something with a substance in order to protect it

examples.text: The floors had been stripped and sealed with varnish.

definitions.definition: to prevent people from passing through a place

examples.text: Troops have sealed the borders between the countries.

definitions.definition: used to say that you will not repeat somebody’s secret to other people
definite, because all the legal documents have been signed

examples.text: The contracts are already signed and sealed.

wordOrigin: verb Middle English (in senses (2), (5) and (6)): from Old French seel (noun), seeler (verb), from Latin sigillum ‘small picture’, diminutive of signum ‘a sign’.
